title: 115_hr4201
content:
The "Young and Beginning Farmers Act" includes provisions for improved access to land and Department of Agriculture training and programs. It covers topics such as land trust eligibility, priority for agricultural land easements, prequalification for credit, increased farm ownership loan limits, and a report on agricultural conservation easement programs. The "Young and Beginning Farmers Act" includes provisions for beginning farmer coordination, transfer of Advisory Committee to Farm Service Agency, online customer self-service portal, training programs, individual development accounts pilot program, sale of surplus farm equipment to disadvantaged farmers, investment in local and regional food systems with funding for farmers' market and local food promotion, and grants for farm viability programs. TITLE I--IMPROVED ACCESS TO LAND

SEC. 101. LAND TRUST ELIGIBILITY FOR ASSISTANCE FOR AGRICULTURAL LAND EASEMENTS.

    (a) Land Trusts.--Qualified land trusts may receive assistance under this section to supplement the sale price of eligible land to farmers or ranchers, while reserving an agricultural land easement for themselves.
    (b) Conforming Amendment.--Section 1001D(b)(1) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions for land trusts to receive assistance. SEC. 102 amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to prioritize applications for agricultural land easements that maintain agricultural viability and require subsequent land purchases at agricultural value. SEC. 103 focuses on prequalifying applicants for credit from Farm Service Agency programs. SEC. 103 requires the Secretary of Agriculture to develop procedures for the Farm Service Agency to provide preliminary credit determinations to prospective loan applicants. SEC. 104 increases the limit on direct farm ownership loans and indexes it to inflation. The Secretary is restricted from making loans that would exceed certain limits based on the value of the security or a set amount, depending on the type of loan. The limits are adjusted for inflation and unpaid indebtedness. The Secretary determines the value of the farm based on competent appraisals. The cost inflation percentage is calculated using the Prices Paid By Farmers Index. Regional farm real estate inflation percentage is also considered for each farm. The Secretary determines farm value through competent appraisals. The regional farm real estate inflation index is developed to measure changes in farm real estate prices in each US region. Microloans program may be established with limitations on total principal indebtedness. The Secretary may establish a microloans program with a limit of $50,000 on total principal indebtedness for each borrower. The application and approval process for microloans should be streamlined to reduce administrative burdens. SEC. 105. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN ON AGRICULTURAL CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROGRAM. Congress acknowledges the importance of the agricultural conservation easement program in assisting beginning farmers and ranchers acquire farmland. The Chief of the Natural Resources Conservation Service must submit a report to Congress evaluating the program's support for beginning farmers and ranchers, along with a plan to address any identified shortcomings to further the program's goals of protecting farmland and helping farmers access it for productive use. TITLE II--IMPROVED ACCESS TO DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TRAINING AND PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. BEGINNING FARMER COORDINATION.

A program will be established to assign a coordinator to each State to facilitate communication between the Department of Agriculture and beginning farmers or ranchers, and to improve their access to apprenticeship programs, farm loans, and land for purchase. The coordinators can be current employees and no new hiring is required. The term "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, and any U.S. territories. SEC. 202. TRANSFER OF ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON BEGINNING FARMERS AND RANCHERS TO JURISDICTION OF FARM SERVICE AGENCY. The Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994 is amended to transfer the Advisory Committee on Beginning Farmers and Ranchers to the jurisdiction of the Farm Service Agency. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to develop an online customer self-service portal for farmers and ranchers to access program information and complete applications. Congress emphasizes that the portal should not disadvantage those without high-speed internet. Appropriations of at least $6,000,000 are authorized for this purpose over a three-year period starting from October 1, 2018. SEC. 204. Beginning Farmer and Rancher Development Program for training, education, outreach, and technical assistance initiatives. Section 7405 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to allow the Secretary to transfer funds for individual development accounts, with a limit of $10,000,000 per year. The Secretary is also restricted to using no more than 4 percent of the transferred funds for administrative costs. Mandatory funding of $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 is allocated from the Commodity Credit Corporation for this purpose. The Secretary is authorized to allocate funds for individual development accounts as follows: $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, $30,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 and 2020, $40,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2021 and 2022, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2023 and beyond. An additional $30,000,000 is authorized for appropriation each fiscal year. These funds remain available until expended. SEC. 205. REAUTHORIZATION OF BEGINNING FARMER AND RANCHER INDIVIDUAL DEVELOPMENT ACCOUNTS PILOT PROGRAM. Authorization of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2023. SEC. 206. SALE OF SURPLUS FARM EQUIPMENT OR PROPERTY TO SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, VETERAN FARMERS, AND BEGINNING FARMERS. The Administrator of General Services can sell surplus farm equipment to socially disadvantaged farmers, veteran farmers, or beginning farmers. Beginning farmers are defined as those who have not operated a farm for more than 10 years and will actively participate in farm operations. The terms "socially disadvantaged farmer or rancher" and "veteran farmer or rancher" are defined in section 2501(e) of the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990. TITLE III--INVESTMENT IN LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS

SEC. 301. MANDATORY FUNDING FOR FARMERS' MARKET AND LOCAL FOOD PROMOTION PROGRAM.

Amends the Farmer-to-Consumer Direct Marketing Act to allocate $50,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2023 to support farmers' markets and local food promotion programs.

SEC. 302. GRANTS TO SUPPORT FARM VIABILITY PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Agriculture may provide grants to support farm viability programs aimed at improving economic viability, integrity, and modernization of farms through farm viability plans and assistance in areas like technical support and land access. $5,000,000 is authorized for grants annually from 2018 to 2023.
